Award.AwardTitle: Past, Present and Fuuture States and Variations of the late Quarternary Permafrost Subsystem
Award.AbstractNarration:
Permafrost and seasonally frozen ground comprise a critically important component of the dynamic arctic terrestrial system, constituting a closely tied subsystem interacting with snow cover, vegetation, and the overlying atmosphere. This permafrost subsystem regulates the local exchange of energy, water, and materials (including carbon and nitrogen), and its influence extends beyond the arctic land to the hydrosphere and the extra-tropical climate. Furthermore, the long timescale of permafrost dynamics requires evaluation of the evolution and impacts of the subsystem on the glacial-interglacial time frame. While some recent numerical projections show rapid and widespread degradation of permafrost in response to climate change during this century, global climate system models with physically based snow and permafrost dynamics have not been fully tested, using new observationally-based evidence, for spatial and temporal variability of the subsystem under different climate conditions such as the Holocene optimum or the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM). Evaluation of the climate sensitivity to the permafrost will provide vital insight to future scenarios, especially in the Northern Hemisphere. The focus will be on three late Quaternary eras for which numerical simulations are widely performed by the collaborative efforts of the Paleoclimate Model Intercomparison Project (PMIP: i.e., the preindustrial present (0 ka, where ka = thousand years before present), mid-Holocene (6 ka), and the LGM (21ka). This project will focus on evaluating the structure and function of the permafrost subsystem under different climate conditions.

The primary questions to be addressed are:
1. How well do the permafrost distributions simulated by global climate models agree with reconstructions from the proxy data?
2. How widely did the permafrost distribution change under different climate conditions? Will permafrost change have serious consequences in nature, life, and societies in the Arctic? Correspondingly, by which processes and interactions does the permafrost subsystem impact the climate of the past and present? How important are the vegetation and soil types?
3. What can we learn from the permafrost subsystem simulations under different climatic conditions to mitigate or adapt to future changes?

Intellectual merits: The reconstructed vegetation map currently available for the climate model inputs will be updated by combining recent results from paleobotanic research, providing a basis for our surface boundary conditions. The simulated results (permafrost distribution) from multiple models as well as the forcing data from the PMIP2 outputs (surface temperature, precipitation [or wetness], and surface wind) will be compared and evaluated with other updated proxy-derived maps. A series of organized numerical sensitivity experiments with different levels of complexity in snow-permafrost dynamics will delineate the essential processes within the permafrost subsystem. Hierarchical experiments of coupled and uncoupled simulations with the atmosphere will quantify the interactions between the atmosphere and the subsurface, and the function of the subsystem as a whole in arctic and global climate.

Broader impacts: broader impact activities will focus on delivering information about direct implications for future climate change projection, and for adaptation planning. Improved scientific understanding of the permafrost subsystem will enhance assessments of the risks of climate change to infrastructure and society, especially on life and culture in the Arctic. This project will also contribute to emerging efforts in earth system modeling, which requires realistic subsurface simulations in order to study the biogeochemical processes that are important for surface exchanges of water vapor and other radiatively active gases. Maps of past permafrost distribution, vegetation and other simulated results in Beringia provide materials to the social and anthropogenic sciences, particularly in such topics as the history of human migration into North America, and the early history of Alaska Natives. It will also facilitate outreach to secondary schools, universities, museums and the general public. Underrepresented student populations such as Alaska Natives, those geographically isolated and economically disadvantaged are among the target audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
[Permafrost subsystem] Permafrost (multi-year freezing ground) is an important component of the eco-climate system in the cold regions. This means permafrost and other components (such as snow cover, water flow and storage, soil, and vegetation) are mutually and strongly connected (Figure 1). Distributions of permafrost and vegetation are not the same through time, have  changed under different past climate, and are changing under ongoing climate change. In the last century, ground temperature has increased and the active layer (seasonally thawed layer) deepened in most of the permafrost regions, whereas depth of seasonal freezing has shallowed in the seasonally frozen ground regions. Over longer periods, they have experienced much larger changes. It is important to know how much they were different in the past, in order to know what they will be in the future, and to what extent we can do to mitigate or prepare for the changes.

This project demonstrated changes in frozen ground distribution at three typical periods in the Late Quaternary, namely, the Last Glacial Maximum (LGM) about 21 thousands years ago (or 21ka; very cold period), mid-Holocene at 6ka (warm period), and the present (0ka). Changes in vegetation for the same time periods, and also projection for future, were simulated in the Arctic, including Beringia (region over East Siberia and Alaska).

The results of the permafrost reconstructions and the biome simulations have important implications for terrestrial ecology and associated ecosystem services in high latitudes.  Wildlife, surface carbon fluxes and human activities are all strongly dependent on the permafrost and vegetative regimes.  Moreover, the distribution of permafrost and vegetation exert strong influences on hydrology.

 

[Frozen ground distribution] Mapping of frozen ground is not easy, even for the present-day distribution, primarily because it is under ground. Compilation of vast field evidence from different areas is needed to make a physically precise map. Approximation maps of reasonable accuracy, however, can be produced using empirical knowledge between permafrost, environment and climate. This project produced frozen ground maps of global coverage at LGM, 6ka and the present-day (Figure 2 for LGM) based on numerical climate simulations, and tested with observations. It shows that areas underlain by permafrost at LGM were more than 50% larger than the present-day areas in the Northern Hemisphere.

A shortcoming of the model outputs is their coarse horizontal resolution (typically, 100 km), which is too coarse to directly compare with field evidence. To facilitate closer examinations with observations, we used fine-resolution surface elevation data to downscale the maps into 2- km resolution. Figure 3 is a product of the project, the first maps of South American frozen ground distribution for the present and LGM period with physical consistency and verification by observations at the fine geographical resolution. Similar maps have been produced for Northeastern Asia (from the Tibetan Plateau and Central Asia to the Pacific coasts), for which such maps have been lacking due to sparse field evidence.
